questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive fatigue and intermittent epigastric pain. He describes the pain as diffuse and 3 out of 10 in intensity. Recently, he has had unusually large black stools. He appears pale. His pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows epigastric tenderness. A urea breath test is positive. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals an ulcerating mass in the gastric antrum. Biopsies of the mass show diffuse infiltrates of small lymphoid cells that are positive for CD20 antigen. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows normal regional lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy with curative intent at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with H. pylori-associated gastric MALT lymphoma, chemotherapy (e.g., a combination of a CD20 antagonist such as rituximab and chlorambucil) is only used if regression of the tumor does not occur with first-line therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection was formerly the treatment of choice for gastric lymphoma. However, evidence shows that negative surgical margins do not ensure a lower risk of recurrence because MALT lymphoma is a multifocal disease of the gastric mucosa. Therefore, the only way to prevent recurrence is to perform a total gastrectomy, which is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Other treatment options are safer and more effective. A gastrectomy is now considered only if the preferred treatments have failed to treat the gastric lymphoma, or if complications such as perforation occur.

C) INCORRECT:

A combination of rituximab, cyclophosphamide, adriamycin, and vincristine is used as a part of the R-CHOP polychemotherapy regimen to treat diffuse large B-cell lymphomas (DLBCL) of the stomach, which can cause epigastric pain and melena. A DLBCL would also be positive for the CD20 antigen. However, a biopsy would show an infiltrative growth of large cells (5 times the size of a lymphocyte) that are arranged in clusters or sheets. R-CHOP therapy is not the treatment of choice for gastric MALT lymphoma, which this patient has.

D) INCORRECT:

Imatinib can be used to treat gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). GISTs most commonly occur in the stomach (60% of cases), are most common in elderly individuals, and can result in epigastric pain as well as melena. However, the biopsy would have shown spindle-shaped epithelioid cells instead of lymphoid cells, and they would not have been positive for CD20. This patient has gastric MALT lymphoma, for which imatinib is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is highly effective in treating H. pylori-associated gastric MALT lymphoma. However, because of its adverse effects (e.g., nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and skin erythema), a safer form of therapy with a comparably high tumor regression rate is preferred as first-line therapy.

F) CORRECT:

H. pylori eradication therapy for 14 days is the first-line treatment for gastric MALT lymphomas. Because of the strong association between MALT lymphomas and H. pylori infection, eradication therapy should be performed even if the patient tests negative. In 60â€“80% of patients with H. pylori-associated gastric MALT lymphoma, eradication therapy results in complete regression of the tumor.

A urea breath test or stool antigen test, as well as an endoscopic biopsy, should be performed three months after therapy to confirm H. pylori eradication and histological response. If there is no or only a partial histological response, radiotherapy or chemotherapy should be initiated.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the stomach

In the antrum, a tumorous process involves almost the entire circumference. The tumor's surface is ulcerated and amorphous (blue overlay). A small area of normal mucosa is visible (dashed line).

These findings are highly concerning for malignancy. Histopathology is necessary to determine the exact diagnosis.
questions.hint: In an elderly patient, fatigue, epigastric pain, melena, a positive urea breath test, and a CD20-positive mass with small lymphoid cells indicate a Helicobacter pylori-associated gastric MALT lymphoma.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of 3 weeks of vague abdominal pain and nausea. He has a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease and received a blood transfusion 10 years ago for severe anemia. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is performed, and a biopsy of the stomach shows diffuse infiltrates of small lymphoid cells that are positive for CD20 antigen. He is diagnosed with extranodal marginal zone lymphoma of the mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue, and treatment is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a nonenveloped, double-stranded, circular DNA virus, and serotypes 16 and 18 are associated with the development of cervical, anal, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma. However, is not associated with an increased risk of gastric MALT lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Clonorchis sinensis is a trematode that causes clonorchiasis. Prolonged infection is associated with the development of cholangiocarcinoma, not gastric MALT lymphoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B virus is a partially double-stranded, circular DNA virus. Chronic hepatitis B infection can lead to the development of hepatocellular carcinoma; approx. 50% of cases are caused by this virus. Hepatitis B can also lead to the development of polyarteritis nodosa, glomerulonephritis, and aplastic anemia, but not MALT lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV-I) is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA retrovirus with an icosahedral capsid that causes adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL) and HTLV-I-associated myelopathy (HAM). It is not associated with an increased risk of gastric MALT lymphoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is a double-stranded DNA herpesvirus. Infection with HHV-8 can lead to the development of Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining malignancy that originates from endothelial cells. It is not associated with gastric MALT lymphoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Schistosoma haematobium is a parasitic blood fluke that causes schistosomiasis. Prolonged infection is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder, not gastric MALT lymphoma.

G) CORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative, spiral-shaped bacterium that mainly infects the gastric mucosa. Infection with H. pylori is the primary risk factor for developing mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma (MALT lymphoma), which this patient has. More than 90% of patients with gastric MALT lymphoma have H. pylori infection. This malignancy is effectively prevented and treated using optimized bismuth quadruple therapy: a combination of tetracycline, metronidazole, bismuth, and a PPI (e.g., esomeprazole). H. pylori is also a risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma (mainly the intestinal type) and peptic ulcer disease. Eradication of the pathogen also decreases the risk of developing these conditions.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a gastric tissue sample (H&E stain, 400x magnification)

There is a dense infiltrate of atypical small lymphocytes between gastric glands, some of which are in the process of being destroyed.

These lymphoepithelial lesions represent a characteristic histological feature of gastric MALT Lymphoma, often associated with H. pylori infection.

H) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus bovis is a gram-positive bacterium that mainly infects the gastrointestinal tract. Infection with S. bovis can result in bacteremia and the subsequent development of subacute endocarditis. Detection of this organism in patients with endocarditis is associated with colorectal cancer, not gastric MALT lymphoma.
questions.hint: The causal pathogen can be seen using the Giemsa stain.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man has had abdominal fullness for several months that has not responded to a 2-month course of omeprazole therapy. He has lost 3 kg due to a lack of appetite.
His examination is within normal limits. An upper endoscopy reveals slightly nodular gastric mucosa. Biopsies of the stomach mucosa reveal Helicobacter pylori infection and dense infiltrates of B-cells of the mucosal lymphoid tissue.
Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imatinib is the treatment for a gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy and gastric resection have no role in treating patients with early-stage gastric MALT lymphoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy and gastric resection have no role in treating patients with early-stage gastric MALT lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

If a MALT lymphoma metastasizes or does not respond to antibiotic treatment, chemotherapy would be the next best treatment option.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, an extranodal lymphoma that can develop in patients with chronic gastritis associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. In patients with early-stage disease, treatment to eradicate the underlying H. pylori infection results in remission of the disease in 50% to 80% of patients.

The recommended first-line treatment for H. pylori infection is bismuth-based quadruple therapy, consisting of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) twice daily, bismuth subsalicylate, metronidazole, and tetracycline. Alternative regimens exist and may be selected on the basis of local resistance patterns and patient-specific factors, such as previous antibiotic exposures or allergies. H. pylori eradication should be confirmed at the conclusion of treatment.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for a patient whose stomach biopsy findings show Helicobacter pylori infection and dense infiltrates of B-cells of the mucosal lymphoid tissue (representing MALT lymphoma) includes antibiotics for the Helicobacter pylori infection. This treatment results in a remission in 50% to 80% of patients with H. pylori-associated gastric mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of epigastric pain, fatigue, and unintended weight loss. She is otherwise stable, with normal vital signs and no lymphadenopathy. Current laboratory tests, including complete blood count, show only mild anemia. No B symptoms are reported. Gastroscopy reveals a shallow gastric ulcer in the antrum. Biopsies show infiltration by atypical lymphoid cells consistent with marginal zone lymphoma. Urea breath testing is positive for Helicobacter pylori, and imaging studies indicate disease limited to the stomach (see lab result).

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in managing this patientâ€™s condition?

choices.text: Local radiation therapy to the stomach
Surgical resection of the affected stomach segment
Antibiotic therapy to eradicate Helicobacter pylori

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Local radiation therapy is used for localized marginal zone lymphomas but is not the initial step when an underlying cause, such as Helicobacter pylori infection, is identified. Radiation does not address the infection and can cause local toxicities. Eradicating H. pylori can lead to lymphoma regression without radiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Combination chemotherapy and immunotherapy are reserved for advanced or refractory lymphomas. In early-stage gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma associated with Helicobacter pylori, antibiotic therapy is preferred due to its effectiveness in inducing remission by addressing the bacterial cause, avoiding the toxicity of systemic treatments.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is considered for complications like bleeding or perforation, not for early-stage gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma linked to Helicobacter pylori. Eradicating the bacterium often leads to lymphoma regression, making surgery unnecessarily aggressive in this context.

D) CORRECT:

Gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma is often associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, which promotes chronic inflammation and B-cell proliferation. When the lymphoma is confined to the stomach, as in this patient, eradicating H. pylori with antibiotics and a proton pump inhibitor is the initial management. This approach targets the underlying cause and can induce lymphoma remission by disrupting the inflammatory processes that support its growth.

Key learning point: H. pylori eradication is the first-line treatment for localized gastric MALT lymphoma associated with H. pylori infection, as it can lead to regression of the lymphoma.
